title: DBMS Level 4 — ER Modeling & Relational Design
concept: Entity–Relationship model, mapping ER to relational schema, keys, participation and relationship types.

challenges.question: In an ER diagram, rectangles typically represent:
challenges.explanation: Rectangles denote entity sets; diamonds denote relationships, ovals denote attributes.

challenges.question: A weak entity set is one that:

options.B: Cannot be represented in a database
options.C: Does not have a primary key and depends on another entity

challenges.explanation: Weak entities lack a key of their own and are identified by a strong (owner) entity plus a partial key.

challenges.question: A multivalued attribute in ER modeling is represented by:
challenges.explanation: Multivalued attributes are shown as double ovals connected to their entity.

challenges.question: Which of the following best describes total participation of entity A in relationship R?

options.A: Some A entities may not participate in R
options.B: Every A entity must participate in at least one R
options.C: No A entity is allowed to participate in R
options.D: Only weak entities can have total participation

challenges.explanation: Total participation means each A must be related via R (represented by double line from A to R).

challenges.question: A 1:N (one-to-many) relationship between A and B is usually implemented in the relational model by:

options.A: Adding a foreign key in table A referencing B
options.B: Adding a foreign key in table B referencing A
options.C: Creating a separate relationship table only
options.D: Storing both tables as a single file

challenges.explanation: For 1:N from A to B, the 'many' side (B) gets a foreign key referencing the 'one' side (A).

challenges.question: A many-to-many (M:N) relationship between Students and Courses is typically mapped to:

options.A: A single table with all attributes of both
options.C: A separate intersection table with foreign keys to Student and Course
options.D: A view only, not a table

challenges.explanation: M:N relationships are represented by a new relation whose primary key usually includes the FKs to both entities.

challenges.question: Which of the following is TRUE about composite attributes?

options.A: They cannot be stored in relational tables
options.B: They are attributes that can be further divided into sub-attributes
options.D: They always act as primary keys

challenges.explanation: Composite attributes (e.g., Address) can be split into simpler attributes like street, city, pin.

challenges.question: In ER to relational mapping, a multivalued attribute of entity E is usually:

options.B: Stored in the same table as E as repeated columns
options.C: Mapped to a separate table with a foreign key to E
options.D: Stored only as a JSON string

challenges.explanation: Multivalued attributes are mapped to a separate relation referencing the owner entity.

challenges.question: An identifying relationship is one in which:

options.B: The primary key of the child entity includes the primary key of the parent entity

challenges.explanation: Identifying relationships are used for weak entities whose PK includes the PK of the owner entity.

challenges.question: Specialization / generalization in ER modeling is used to:
challenges.explanation: Specialization/generalization captures inheritance-like IS-A relationships between entity sets.
